[[File:Avro Shackleton MR3 WR977 B (6806414794).jpg|thumb|WR977 'B – [[The Herbs#The characters|Basil]]' at [[Newark Air Museum]]. Orange Harvest can be seen just forward of the outboard propeller tips|alt=Front half of a Shackleton aircraft. The Orange Harvest antenna is visible as a ribbed white cylinder on top of the fuselage.]] '''Orange Harvest''' was an [[Electronic Support Measures|ESM]] receiver fitted to marine patrol [[Avro Shackleton]]s during the [[Cold War]].
Orange Harvest was an [[S band]] and [[X band]] [[radar warning receiver]], capable of giving a directional bearing to surface ships or submarines that were transmitting radar emissions. Although less precise than the Shackleton's main ASV.21 search radar, it could give a greater detection range,<ref name="Flight, Airborne Watchkeeper, 1969" /> provided that the target was emitting. As a passive system, it also had the advantage that it did not betray the aircraft's presence to its target.
A particular target would be the [[I band]]{{efn-lr|The NATO I band definition overlaps the lower range of the IEEE-defined X band.}} RLK-101 ''Albatros'' (NATO [[Snoop Tray]]) and MRK-50 [[Snoop Pair]] radars used by the early Soviet nuclear submarines. As these boats could now run continually submerged, without even needing to [[submarine snorkel|snorkel]], they were increasingly difficult to detect by previous methods, such as [[Autolycus (submarine detector)|Autolycus]] or search radar.
Electrically there were two quite separate systems: wide- and narrow band, but sharing the same external antenna housing. The wide band receiver was made by [[Rank Organisation|Rank]] in Plymouth. The narrow band receiver derived from an early [[ELINT]] receiver called 'Breton', developed in [[de Havilland Comet|Comet]]s by [[No. 51 Squadron RAF|51 Squadron]].
The external [[antenna (radio)|antenna]] for Orange Harvest was the distinctive white dielectric '[[spark plug]]' carried on the upper surface of the Shackleton.<ref name="Gibson, 20" /> This 'spark plug' has often been mis-identified as an insulator for a [[HF radio|HF]] [[random wire antenna|long-wire antenna]] running to the aircraft's tail. It is actually self-contained, and at a wavelength far shorter than would use long wires. The Shackleton did carry HF antennae, but these were supported by two small metal masts, just ahead of Orange Harvest. The structural fitment for Orange Harvest was a metal plinth built into the fuselage, at approximately the previous dorsal turret position. The large antenna was fastened to this. As the antenna causes significant drag, it was sometimes removed and only the plinth was evident.<ref name="Avroshackleton, Ballykelly" /> This was more common in the 1960s ASW era, rather than the later AEW period.
[[File:Shackleton-WR982-303.jpg|thumb|Shackleton interior and operator positions. Orange Harvest is at the very far left|alt=View inside the Shackleton cabin, looking forward past the row of operator desks along the port side.]] The interior display for Orange Harvest was a 3" cathode ray tube, in front of the C operator.<ref name="8 Squadron, Orange Harvest" />
Orange Harvest was introduced with the [[Avro Shackleton#Shackleton MR.Mk.3 Phase 2|Shackleton MR.3 Phase II]] in 1961.{{sfnp|Gibson|2015|page= 87 }} After the replacement of Shackleton with [[Nimrod MR.1]] in the [[anti-submarine warfare|ASW]] role, Orange Harvest continued with the Shackleton AEW.2 aircraft of [[No. 8 Squadron RAF#Post War operations|8 Squadron RAF]] from 1972 to 1991.<ref name="Flight, RAF early-warner, 1973" /><ref name="8 Squadron, Orange Harvest" />
